                    ### Question
                    Which of the following can be blocked by atropine, a muscarinic receptor blocker?

                    ### Options
                    opa. Increased blood pressure caused by nicotine
opb. Increased skeletal muscle strength caused by neostigmine, an acetycholine esterase inhibitor
opc. Bradycardia caused by infusion of acetylcholine
opd. All of these

### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
Atropine, a muscarinic receptor antagonist, effectively blocks bradycardia caused by acetylcholine by preventing its action on muscarinic receptors in the heart. It does not affect increased blood pressure from nicotine or increased skeletal muscle strength from neostigmine, as these are mediated by nicotinic receptors, which atropine does not block. Therefore, among the given options, atropine can only block the bradycardia caused by acetylcholine.
